title: Trumenba Intramuscular: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Trumenba intramuscular on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) is used to help prevent certain serious, sometimes fatal, [bacterial infections](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections) ( [meningitis](https://www.webmd.com/children/understanding-meningitis-basics), [meningococcemia](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/meningococcemia)). loss](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/hearing-loss-causes-symptoms-treatment), [brain](www.webmd.com/brain/picture-of-the-brain-vue3)/nerve problems, [paralysis](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/sleep-paralysis), blindness, [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics), loss of limbs) even with antibiotic treatment. This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) works by increasing the body's natural defense ( [immunity](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/10-immune-system-busters-boosters)) against the bacteria that cause [meningococcal disease](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/meningococcemia).Vaccination is the best way to prevent infection. However, like any vaccine, it may not fully protect everyone who receives it.The brand and dose of vaccine you receive depend on your age. Other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) may also be given at the same time, usually in a different site on the body. How to use Trumenba Syringe Read all [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before receiving the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. This vaccine is given by injection into a muscle by a health care professional. Adults and children usually receive the injection in the upper arm, and infants receive it in the upper thigh. Depending on your age, the vaccine is given one or more times. Ask your health care professional for your recommended vaccine schedule. Since fever may commonly occur after vaccination (especially in infants and children), your health care professional may recommend a fever/pain relief [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) (such as [acetaminophen](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-362/acetaminophen+oral/details)) for use if needed. Ask your health care professional for details. Side Effects Pain/redness/swelling at the injection site, [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics), fever, chills, drowsiness, tiredness, [joint](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/joint-pain)/ [muscle pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/myofascial-pain-syndrome), [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), loss of appetite, or [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea) may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional promptly. Rarely, some people have symptoms such as [fainting](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics), [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes, or [ringing in the ears](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-tinnitus-basics) just after getting a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) injection. Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional right away if you have any of these symptoms. Sitting or lying down may help, since these symptoms usually don't last long. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your health care professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your health care professional right away if you have any serious side effects, including: numbness/tingling, muscle [weakness](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/weakness-and-fatigue-topic-overview). A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the Vaccine Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before receiving this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as latex found in some brands), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before receiving this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: current fever/illness, a certain nerve disease ( [Guillain](https://www.webmd.com/brain/what-is-guillain-barre)-Barre syndrome), [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment). This drug may make you drowsy. Alcohol or [marijuana](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/marijuana-use-and-its-effects) ( [cannabis](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/marijuana-use-and-its-effects)) can make you more drowsy. Do not drive, use machinery, or do anything that needs alertness until you can do it safely. Limit [alcoholic](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/understanding-alcohol-abuse-basics) beverages. Talk to your doctor if you are using marijuana (cannabis). During pregnancy, this vaccine should be used only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your health care professional. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) include: drugs that Not applicable. Keep [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) records for yourself and your children. After your children are grown, give them a record to share with their [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professionals to help prevent unnecessary re- [vaccinations](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation). It is important that you or your child receive each vaccination as scheduled. Be sure to ask when each dose should be received, and make a note on a calendar to help you remember. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Different brands of this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) may have different storage needs. Check the product package for instructions on how to store your brand, or ask your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your pharmacist or local waste disposal company.
